articles.title: Blackburn's $5.35M Haul — And the 78% Problem
articles.summary: Blackburn's first campaign finance disclosure reveals massive fundraising from 33,000 contributions — so many it briefly crashed the state's filing system. But 78% of her money came from out-of-state donors, giving Rose a potent contrast.

articles.title: Rose Reports $6.46M War Chest, Hammers In-State Donor Contrast
articles.summary: Rose's finance report shows $1.46M raised plus a $5M personal loan. His 92% in-state donor rate is now central to his campaign messaging against Blackburn's out-of-state fundraising.

articles.title: Tennessee governor leaves immigration enforcement out of final address
articles.summary: House Republicans continued their push to toughen immigration laws days before Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee made his final State of the State address. But the governor didn’t talk about immigration Monday night, heading into the last year of his two terms. The omission was not lost on Democratic state Re...

articles.title: Tennessee governor urges better Nashville Electric Service efforts in winter storm
articles.summary: With tens of thousands of Nashville Electric Services customers still without power, Gov. Bill Lee encouraged the utility to improve communications and transparency five days after a winter storm struck. NES is drawing criticism about its response to the historic storm after turning down some outsid...

articles.title: Fritts Calls for Execution Over Transgender Care for Minors
articles.summary: State Rep. Monty Fritts appears on a podcast advocating capital punishment for parents, guardians, and medical providers involved in gender-affirming care for minors. The clip goes viral via Right Wing Watch, drawing national attention and bipartisan criticism.

articles.title: Beacon Poll: Blackburn at 56%, Rose Stalled at 9% Despite Ad Blitz
articles.summary: The January 2026 Beacon Center/TennSight poll of 1,200 registered voters shows Blackburn's lead narrowing from 68% (Aug) to 56%, but Rose hasn't gained — he's actually dropped from 14% to 9%. Fritts has risen to 7%, and 28% of Republican voters remain undecided. The growing undecided pool is the real story.

articles.title: With landfills filling up, Tennessee legislature once again looks at recycling bills
articles.summary: Tennessee’s slow uptake of recycling is costing the state — in economic opportunity and dwindling landfill space — according to multiple presentations to the state’s newly formed Solid Waste Task Force. With the bill filing deadline for the 2026 legislative session looming at the end of the month, t...

articles.title: Even conservative Supreme Court justices cool to Trump dismissal of the Fed’s Lisa Cook
articles.summary: WASHINGTON — U.S. Supreme Court justices across the political spectrum appeared skeptical of President Donald Trump’s swift, informal dismissal of Federal Reserve Board Governor Lisa Cook, and his effort to influence the independent central bank that governs monetary policy in the United States. The...

articles.title: Tennesseans need representatives who oppose regime change and endless war
articles.summary: In the days following the Trump administration’s kidnapping of Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro, Tennessee’s Republican lawmakers took to social media to praise the congressionally unauthorized attack.  U.S. Sens. Marsha Blackburn and Bill Hagerty referenced allegations against Maduro for his sup...

articles.title: Preview of the 2026 Legislative Session
articles.summary: Tennessee Firefly previews the major education bills and political dynamics heading into the 2026 session — including how the governor's race is shaping legislative priorities on vouchers, teacher pay, and school funding.

articles.title: Carnita Atwater Files for Governor — Third Major Race in Four Years
articles.summary: Memphis community leader and museum president enters the Democratic primary. Her third attempt at major office — she ran for governor in 2022 (3rd in the Democratic primary) and Memphis mayor in 2023.

articles.title: Four Independents File for Governor
articles.summary: Stephen Maxwell, Lauren Pinkston, Manasa Reddy, and Robert Vick all file as independent candidates. Maxwell — a nonprofit director, minister, and military veteran — is the only one to complete a detailed policy survey.

articles.title: Beacon Poll: Blackburn Drops to 58%, Undecideds Surge to 28%
articles.summary: The November 2025 Beacon Center/TennSight quarterly poll shows Blackburn's support declining 10 points from August while Rose dropped from 14% to 9%. The undecided pool has doubled from 14% to 28%, suggesting Republican voters are less locked in than August numbers implied.

articles.title: Congressman John Rose Discusses His Run for Governor
articles.summary: TNFirefly's On The Fly podcast sits down with Rep. Rose for an in-depth interview on his gubernatorial campaign. Covers his background in agriculture, IT entrepreneurship, education stance, and why he decided to leave Congress.

articles.title: Monty Fritts Announces at 'Trump Day' Dinner
articles.summary: State Rep. Fritts announces his candidacy at the Washington County Republican Party event in Johnson City. Running as anti-establishment — one of ~20 House Republicans who voted against the school voucher bill. Campaigns on 'Liberty & Less Government.'

articles.title: Blackburn Enters the Race — Reshapes the Entire Field
articles.summary: U.S. Senator Marsha Blackburn announces her candidacy for governor, instantly becoming the Republican frontrunner. Close Trump ally with statewide name recognition. Several potential candidates decide not to run in the wake of her announcement.

articles.title: Beacon Center Poll: Blackburn 68%, Rose 14% in Republican Primary
articles.summary: First major poll of the race shows Blackburn with a commanding lead among likely Republican primary voters. Rose sits at 14%, with Fritts and Pellegra in low single digits. In a hypothetical general, Blackburn leads Green 49-28.

articles.title: Jerri Green Launches 'One Tough Mother' Campaign
articles.summary: Memphis City Council member enters the Democratic primary. Georgetown Law grad, former public defender, three-time gun violence survivor, and former statewide lead for Moms Demand Action. Plans an 'army of moms' grassroots campaign.

articles.title: Rose Reports $1.1M Raised, Loans Campaign $5M
articles.summary: Rose's first finance disclosure shows strong fundraising plus a massive personal loan. His 92% in-state donor rate becomes a key differentiator. Launches statewide TV and mail ads — the first candidate to go on air.

articles.title: 'Ditch' Kurtz Launches Grassroots Campaign at East Nashville Venue
articles.summary: Nashville pedal steel guitarist Adam 'Ditch' Kurtz announces his Democratic campaign at The 5 Spot. Running on a no-corporate-money pledge with education as his '#1 priority.' Supports free pre-K, marijuana legalization with tax revenue to schools, and eliminating the grocery tax.

articles.title: John Rose Becomes First Major Candidate to Enter the Race
articles.summary: U.S. Rep. John Rose (TN-6) formally launches his campaign. A family farmer and IT businessman who served as Commissioner of Agriculture under both Bredesen and Haslam, Rose positions himself as a pragmatic conservative with bipartisan governing experience.

articles.title: Beacon Poll: April 2024 Results
articles.summary: Today, we released our fourth quarterly Beacon Poll, a statewide survey of 1,197 registered Tennessee voters comprised of questions about political races, policy issues, and more. In the Tennessee Senate race that is garnering national attention, the new Beacon Poll finds incumbent Senator Marsha Bl...
